[*]There are light elements of romance along with love triangles. However its never fully fleshed out.
[*]Lots of world building and political court intrigue.The NPCs are alive in the video game world. Our adventurers are the outsiders. All of this gets blended together beautifully.\n\n
Ultimately, Log Horizon is a good show and it's certainly worth checking out.  It's slow paced nature and a few boring episodes tend to drag down the enjoyment factor just a bit.

After I discovered my passion to online games and see how it fits in the anime I decided to watch Sword Art Online, No Game No Life. I think Log Horizon is a better choice for me because of the strategical moves in combat and economical-political issues. 
I like how they introduce us the world-Elder Tale- with a smart character. You can catch the basics of the game after a few episodes. If you are already a game player it can be more enjoyable. There is always new things you can discover about the games. I was really suprised they understand that the world's rulesis different from the game and you can cook, build with your skills. 


Characters are very likeable. I found all of them interesting. I thought I would bored when they are educating the lower levels. But it also help me to get team playing in the game and I like how they are attaching each other and in this way improve their combat. 


Some parts is heavy but if you enjoy how to build a society and solve the problems you can adapt easily. 


I still wonder about the character's real world stories and what happened to their bodies. I hope we can learn about it more in the next seasons.


At last I enjoyed so much. The combats, character's interactions, build a society concept are perfect for my taste.

Even with the two nines I still give a overall 10 to Log Horizon as it has become one of my most memorable animes I have seen.  I know quite a few people love Sword Art Online but why are we kidding ourselves, SAO originally started off with a solid story random people being trapped in a MMORPG universe but it quickly dissolved when they decided to cram two different games into one single season.  Log Horizon however did not fall for this same major issue but being consistent.  These people are trapped in Elder Tale and they have no idea whenthey'll get home or even if they'll get home.  Another thing that really kept my interest is you see the players actively using their combat/ui hud throughout the series, blast to the past another great series that did this was .hack//sign.  This series is about the people that played on the Yamamoto Server of Elder Tale (a popular MMORPG at the time) when they suddenly find themselves trapped in the game.  This event will later become known as The Cataclysm and throughout the series the characters don't make futile unbelievable attempts at escaping instead they try to find a way to live with their circumstances.  Shiro the series protagonist (also known as Villain in Glasses) mainly because his motives for the greater good sometimes become misconstrued by others around him.  Shiro is the leader of a guild (after The Cataclysm) called Log Horizon and people also known him before The Cataclysm as a member of the legendary party known as Debauchery Tea Party.  This series is worth the watch if you enjoy shonen and game related animes.

The story is quite normal, but it has no emotion / excitement. If the characters die, they are reborn and only lose "some memories". There is no point that catches your eye, only the protagonist Shiroe, is interesting.
The art of the characters and environment, along with the background music, do not call attention, are normal and just complement the adventure, nothing surprising. That's what I missed.
Most characters are silly. They are only useful for the jokes, for the story are totally unnecessary. Henrietta and Marielle are characters that should have been important to the story, but only serve to make too many reactions. "Aaah, howbeautiful you look in that dress" or "aaah, let me hug you Naotsugu" ... this is embarrassing. Only characters that delay me are Shiroe and Nyanta, the rest do not even remember the names. This is very sad.


Overall, I can say that I did not like it so much, but I did not hate it either. It's an ordinary anime. It did not mark me negatively or positively. Is this a good thing?


I do not know, the only thing I know is that I do not feel like watching Season Two, because there was no mystery to be solved there. Back home? I swear that does not interest me.

This review is from a Brazilian.

Please keep in mind that this is my opinion of Log Horizon. It is also my first review so please don't be too critical.
Story:
The story is about our main characters  finding themselves in a world similar to Elder Tale- an MMOPRG that they all played. Now the characters have to find out why that has happened and how to get back to their world. 
What I love about the story telling of this anime is that they don't immediately jump to characters trying to find their way home. The characters actually take time to explore the world and learn how is it different fromthe game they are used to playing. As a result, this creates world building and helps us learn more about the characters. 

What I don't like is the fact that the show very heavy on exposition and character interaction and there is no sense of urgency from the characters on wanting to get back home. As a result, sometimes the story feels slow pace. 


Art:


Since the anime is mostly runs on character interaction and exposition, there is not a lot of action sequences as a result the animation during those scenes are not very exceptional but it is better than average and watchable. With that being said, the animation during some of the background sceneries were lovely and memorable. 


Sound:


The soundtrack in this anime is very well done. None of the tracks seemed out of place with any of the scenes to me and some of the tracks were especially memorable. I also love the opening. It was the same opening for all 25 episodes of the show and I did not skip it on any episode.


Character:


Log Horizon has a large cast of diverse main characters. With that being said, none of the main characters were ever side tracked. Every character had a role to play in the overall story arc. This could range from being the star of the arc to being a source of motivation for the character despite only having one conversation with the character. They also try to make sure that the main characters have some form of development. 

The downside is that because there is such a large cast, the characters does not receive as much development as they could have.


Enjoyment:


I personally enjoyed this anime a lot. I have not watched a lot MMORPG  anime, because sometimes it's hard for me to follow the story but this anime really helped understand the story due to the heavy exposition and explanation. I also liked how the anime stayed true to it's MMORPG style and  yet did something very unique and different compare to it's predecessor. 

Also, while the characters may lack development, they are memorable and unique when compared to their stereotypes and I also enjoyed watching them interact with one another and with the world they are living in. 


Overall:


I recommend this anime to anyone who loves MMORPG style games because of how it's sticks true to it's MMORPG style and too anyone who doesn't mind if they show is more based on character interaction and exposition rather than action. I also recommend it to those who don't mind a slow paced story.

As someone who's already reading Light Novels such as Overlord and The Legendary Moonlight Sculptor, the core concept of the 'people in a MMORPG' isn't new. However, sometimes all you need is a tried and tested formula which has been executed well and in that regard Log Horizon is a great show to watch.
The one aspect which sets this show apart from contemporaries like Overlord is how it handles the 'MMO' part of the MMORPG setting. Game mechanics, their consequences and their effect on not just combat but also the world in general has been well thought out and makes sense within the realmof the plot setting. While the show does have it's share of powerful individuals, it balances their abundance of power with adequate plot development. Obviously there are a few predictable tropes with regards to the comedy and the interpersonal dynamics of a guild, however, all that is done in appropriate quantities and it doesn't take your attention away from the plot. \n\n
In many respects, the show is like Nanatsu No Taizai. It doesn't have a complicated or unique story, but the way the story has been executed makes watching it fresh and entertaining. Furthermore, this show has shown to me the importance of being a man with glasses (you'll understand what I mean when you watch the show). Looking forward to munching down the second season, and while a third season seems unlikely, I guess I'll just keep enjoying the after taste after I finish watching it all.

Review in brief: Season 1 of Log Horizon presents a truly faithful rendition of the "trapped in an MMO" setting and provides an interesting story to go with it but suffers from slow progression and predictability. Your enjoyment will hinge on how well you stay immersed in the world of Elder Tale and while this anime does a good job of getting you to enter there's no guarantee that it will hold you in.
Review in full: When it comes to engagement, Log Horizon places heavy focus on just one aspect: immersion. It wants you to enter its world, explore both its realms and game-like mechanics,experience the cultures of the pre-existing NPCs and the newly trapped gamers, and ultimately feel like you're on an adventure in the world of Elder Tale yourself. This is accomplished quite well. Right from the get-go the characters realize that they must use the mechanics of the game (including classes, cool-down abilities, and now-telepathic voice chat) to thrive, but they are all still gamers at heart and also start developing new strategies to handle everything from cooking to spell-casting.


While this is going on there are bigger implications that are explored in a game world made real. What happens when NPCs are no longer just walking dialogue boxes but living, breathing beings? Or when magic is no longer just game code and becomes a real form of energy? Even politics and the economy become major issues as time goes on. Being trapped in a video game isn't just a gimmick or plot device in Log Horizon, it's the very essence of everything it is and does.  Together with the well-established setting (which is continuously being fleshed out) it creates the captivating sense that the story is much bigger than just what we see the characters going though.  Even when Log Horizon wasn’t enjoyable for me, this sense gave me reason to believe that something more was just an episode away.


As far as production values go, the animation does a great job of displaying both the world and the video game elements without either looking out of place.  This is including the CG, as even though it stands out compared to the animation at times it still feels like it belongs in the context of how it’s being used. The familiar yet fantastical designs of the environments and the characters also do a remarkable job of making it all feel like its own world as well as its own game, cultivating strong visual immersion to complement its narrative immersion. Meanwhile the music, sound effects, and voice-work (I watched in Japanese) is good (but not great) all around.  It does its job and there isn't anything to complain about but not much of it is memorable either (aside from the oddly catchy OP).


Sadly, beyond that Log Horizon's presentation transforms the story from an intricate exercise in how a world can be built from the mechanics that drive it into a lazy shounen adventure adaptation where the premise is only used as a hook to get you to watch the next episode each week. It's as though the story is being held hostage by the producers, demanding that you watch more than what's necessary to continue.  This is largely due to the show’s slow progression.  It's not much of an issue early on since there's initially quite a bit that the anime has to and does explain, but after the first third of the season it finds itself with too little to explain to justify the pace and starts spacing itself out instead.


After the world is established each subsequent arc features a barrage of recaps, which not only include the typical beginning-of-the-episode refreshers but also many mid-episode reminders, cues, and hints; so many in fact that by the time each arc comes to a head so many hints have been dropped that you know how the arc ends before it even reaches a climax, destroying the dramatic build-up of tension the intricate story naturally contains.  It's like reading a good book next to an acquaintance who is constantly asking if you've reached the next big spoilery event, with no attempt to mask the spoiler itself.  These are then interlaced with so much shallow comedy (especially with the pervert jokes and ship-teases that you'd have to be blind to not see coming) and boring filler (such as pointless side plots and clearly one-sided battles) that it all takes up more time than the serious moments that progress the plot.  Everything that actually matters could have been covered in 13 episodes with room to spare, but Log Horizon doesn't trust its viewers to understand or remember anything that takes more than two sentences to explain.


In addition, while Log Horizon's characters are utilized well by the story, the characters themselves are mostly nothing special. The majority of them fill a role, perform that role, and nothing more, while most of the rest don’t even manage that. Development and backstories beyond a few bullet-points (predictable clichés included) are for but a select few characters. You'll likely find two or three of them to be particularly interesting, but many of them are easily forgettable. There is even a plot development tied to the game's XP system that offers a great opportunity to take a closer look at the characters in that moment before things change for them, but nothing substantial was done with it and it passed with just a brief mention. It also doesn't help that there's very little that is able to challenge them. The fact that the trapped gamers are overpowered even becomes a plot point, though again it’s merely stated rather than addressed. Regardless it doesn’t help that few characters have any real reason to develop when all they have to do is listen to Shiroe for everything to turn out okay (or if they’re one of the handful of cookie-cutter villains, wait for Shiroe to defeat them because they had no chance to win in the first place).


Verdict:  Log Horizon’s first season could have easily been great, in fact it definitely was for the first third, but its faults severely damage the majority of the show.  Even then I could almost still say it’s good because underneath all of the mindless filler & overused tropes lies an interesting concept, quality production values, and the beginnings of an amazing plot.  Unfortunately, the product as a whole just isn’t entertaining or intricate enough to cope with its faults.  I can’t recommend Log Horizon to a general audience, though if you’re a big fan of isekai or anime about video games you may find enough to enjoy here to make it all worthwhile.

Log Horizon is a story of being trapped within the world of Elder Tales, an MMO game. I watched the anime and read the light novels. Its protagonist is Shiroe, an enchanter with a wicked reputation. We follow him as he deals with the reality of being trapped in the game world. He meets a zany cast of characters as he tries to find a way back to the real world.
I thought it had a good premise and was well executed. It doesn't uplift anime or light novels as a medium but offered an adequate story of discovery and adventure for the audience. One ofthe weaknesses of Japanese anime and light novels is the overuse of the same tropes and cliches. They are present here but thankfully don't detract the fun from the story. 


Log Horizon will undoubtedly be compared to 2012's hit series Sword Art Online. I consider Log Horizon to be the superior due to its more realistic portrayal of human psychology and the non-presence of blatant wish fulfillment.


Log Horizon doesn't suffer from many weaknesses but it does nothing to differentiate itself from what has been done before. As I am really fond of numerical values I give the first season of Log Horizon a 4/5.


P.S. The opening song Database was definitely one of the catchiest I've heard yet.

for this particular anime there have bin many who find it to be a failed remake of sword art online,most of which have never watched an episode, it has the same concept behind the story line but is in far more depth than that of sao don't get me wrong sao is amazing but in its own way. this takes on a  more intellectual perspective in many regards with both the story and fighting, its a more team based anime with the bigger picture in mind instead of a straight up one way goal.
log horizon is constantly trying to keep the viewers on therefeet with sharp wits and deception behind every plot. the anime is very diverse and wide ranged in all aspects such as the races, buildings and dignitaries, overall the anime is visually unique in the way where much in the surroundings are very modern but degraded again keeping u on your feet and curious. this anime as a whole is very unique with a simple concept behind it but with enough depth to keep u both attached and interested in the story and characters it doesn't so much focus on one individual character but more as the group as a whole and gets u more attached to each individual character i would highly recommend it to those who enjoyed sao but thought it to childish or to those who simply enjoy some serious depth.

If I could I would break up this review into 2 parts: episodes 1-10~ and the rest. The first part is a well executed mix of exposition, economical and political maneuvering, a bit of interesting combat and generally the efforts of our main characters to quickly forge a stable civilization from the sudden chaos the world was plunged into after everyone was sucked into the MMO. 
Watch genius Shiro use his intricate knowledge of the game's rules as well as his charisma and reputation to establish order among the chaotic society of MMO players. 
The second part however, is much less interesting. It focuses heavilyon a group of kids just learning the game, some diplomatic wrangling with one of the NPC countries and preparing for some war against a horde of goblins.

What this series brings to the table is a look into the lives of individuals who are trapped in a video game, more specifically an MMO rpg. This is actually nothing new in the realm of anime, but that matters not so as long as its execution is well done. Unfortunately this is were it falls short, since it's entire set up lends itself to underwhelming drama, being that characters don't die when they are killed. (yes that was intentional) With this revelation, much of what was a stake feels lost, although they could have gone in a direction that expands upon other consequences ofexisting in this world being that it is not the one they once knew, which they do address to some extent, but they are all underplayed to the point where it seems they don't even really pose a great treat or concern beyond moving the plot forward. 


Speaking of the plot, The everyday life of people in a video game is what the series should be called, since not much exploration into the nature of being an alternate persona (Which .hack//sign addresses), political intrigue or the relationship between the supposed people of the land and the adventures is really present beyond the superficial and in some ways childish. Everything lends itself to be treated like another quest to go out and complete, which ironically works against the show in trying to build a coherent narrative. 


The show also tries to act smart many times almost as if it's trying to prove that it's not a typical shounen, however everything is explained exactly when it happens for the first time in the series, which means the classic case of someone standing still and explaining what he just did in the middle of a heated battle.


What this show I do admit does well is the atmosphere and feeling of being in an MMO rpg, which despite never really having played one that in depth, they definitely did their homework. (unlike Sword Art Online) Though the more I watch of the show the more it felt like a gimmick rather than something the show was using to create an engaging narrative, with characters being quite one note due to a lack of potential within the story for any catharsis. The characters are fun enough for the style this show goes for, but are not deep or complicating in any way. They are easily defined by a few quirks and simple mentalities, which is usually there just for the sake of laughs as the anime is very easy going. 


Overall, I'd say the anime does try do be more than your typical anime, but it holds itself back with what could have been done with its set up and fails to fully deliver, as it takes itself way to easy being only enjoyable for those who want there anime about MMOs to make sense, which at the very least, it achieves that.

4 Words
NOT Sword Art Online.
Whilst SAO had arguably superior art there is something charming about the art and character design in log horizon from Shiroe to Regan. The characters I say make a show. Here there are loads which I find great especially as they are all unique....well except that everyone has a hidden skill....PUSHING YOUR GLASSES SLIGHTLY UP!!! When this happens you know something is about to happen. Shiroe isn't called the "Villian behind Glasses" for nothing! The settings and background art are great.
This series plays on the idea that you have just got out of dreary old work and are shut in agame. But you have no idea apart there was an update. Who would want to go from fun game to school and work..*cough* SAO *cough*.


Log Horizon also understands the concept of MMOs. One of its greatest attributes is that it takes time to explain the world from politics to geography and servers to attacks. Every attack has a background and when first used Shiroe or another character explains it, its fascinating. Talking about attacks, its also fun to see the 3 main characters start at Max level 90, but the limit has just been raised to 100, its not some generic shounen where friendship, love and randomly swinging a sword around solves it all *cough* SAO *cough*.


Whilst there is lots of talking it just adds to the world it creates. On this topic whilst some may disagree and say sub is better I watched sub then dub but I found the dub better for me. Some disagree with Mike Yager as Shiroe but I love his voice as Shiroe its bland and bleak...like a strategist should be - calm not screaming like Kirito! Akatsuki and Crusty also had great dub actors.


Whilst the music can be repetitive I liked it..not sure why but I loved it and DATABASE DATABASE at the start of each episode is a guilty pleasure. The writing for the script is amazing and congrats to Mamare Touno for the great Light Novel source. He understands politics, economics, under handed tactics and of course MMOs.


Animation? Standard but endearing!


Now the story....adapting and waiting not screaming, panicking and trying to escape. This allows a world of monsters and events which seem basic to a gamer but in reality in log horizon forgetting an event can cost you dearly just wait for it! Royalty, commoners and bending the rules. Log horizons base game the one they are stuck in is called "Eldertale" and has lots of mechanisms for peace and fair play. But its great when Shiroe and other characters exploit loopholes as they are now able to do many more things than when the put commands into a computer.


By the way Season 2 is awesome!!! Especially the first half and the last few episodes.


Overall 10/10 for having a great story, great characters, great setting, great ideas, great writing, atmosphere, world building and did I mention endearing characters?!?!?!


Give it a watch. Both seasons. But on season 1 dubbed at the moment I think. By the way Satelight animate the 1st season but for reasons DEEN got the 2nd Cour! Well enjoy it and you can't hate Akatsuki! BY THE WAY IT IS NOT SWORD ART ONLINE I think it's insulting that people compare them and say Log Horizon is a rip off of SAO. SAO probably stole from .back, and if we went like this then you could say anime steals from everyone.


Well I enjoyed it and let's hope Mamare Touno gets a few more light novels out so we can have season 3!!!


For other suggestions I would point you to SAO to see the major differences for yourself but I warn you its very bad for your health! Another good anime is Maoyu maou Yuusha also by Mamare Touno. And finally not so related is Rokka no Yuusha but it also has great characters, story and setting where they are also trapped but in a much smaller area, both anime make you think.


I hope you learn something from this review and all the best to you!


P.S. This was my first review if you couldn't tell from the sloppiness :)

WARNING! CONTAINS SPOILERS! READ AT YOUR OWN RISK!
Look, Log Horizon is a great anime. I cannot add any more to what has already been said by those who are praising it, because honestly, I’d do the same. But what needs to be said has already been said. So what the hell am I here for? To rant about one aspect (call me crazy and overdramatic) that needs to be voiced.
*Inhale*
*BEEP* romance! *BEEP* it right in the *BOOP*!
How many times have I watched an anime where they shoehorned a piece of shite relationship they call “romance” and expect me to nod my head and let itpass on through? No! I’m sick of it! I’m sick of people adding romance into an anime when it’s not needed! What the hell is the point of adding romance into Log Horizon? Tell me! Is the writer catering to the female audience or something? Or do guys actually enjoy reading about love triangles too? Because I sure as hell am sick of it! If I wanted to watch romance, I’d go watch a damn shoujo or something labeled as “romance”.


But when romance is added into my shounen, I get sick of it!


Look, maybe I’m making the wrong impression here. I don’t mind romance. I mind horribly done romance. And I’m not talking about Shiroe and Akatsuki (even though I’m also sick of the loli-fetish but that’s another rant for another day). By the way, if you haven't noticed, I'm getting sick of a lot of things these days.


WARNING! THIS IS WHERE THE SPOILER IS! IT’S ABOUT THE ROMANCE IN LOG HORIZON (OBVIOUSLY) SO IF YOU DON’T CARE ABOUT THAT SHITE, THEN READ ON IF YOU MUST!


What the hell was the point of having Minori fall for Shiroe? Huh? Someone tell me! Oooo, now there’s tension between Minori, Akatsuki, and Shiroe! How interesting!


NO! That shite was boring as hell and completely unnecessary! Seriously? Shiroe was a teacher figure to Minori, a big brother figure. But no, she ends up falling for him? Wha? Why? How? But most of all WHY? The creator(s) better have a damn good reason for having this stupid love triangle pop out of nowhere from Log Horizon’s ass!


Some of you may say I’m making a big deal out of this, but believe me, these little "details" matter too. Of course, I will give Log Horizon 2 a chance once it’s finished. But I swear, if that *BEEP*ing love triangle is shoved into my face again, I’m going to go super saiyan and choke whoever thought it was a good idea to add a love triangle into this series in the first place!

WARNING, MAY CONTAIN MINOR SPOILERS!
Log Horizon
Review By: John Fragglepuss Evans
Be warned, Log Horizon is not Sword Art Online. If you go into this anime expecting it to be the same as SAO, you will most likely be disappointed. If you start watching Log Horizon with an open mind and an open heart, you will have a much better chance at enjoying it. Also, there  is subtle humor throughout Log Horizon, which is well-placed.
You might enjoy this if: You are on the prowl for a lot of strategic, political action. Also, if you are looking for a gentleman cat-person, you found your anime!
You might notlike it if: You are on the hunt for the battle-scene action.


Note to the Viewer: This is not Sword Art Online.


EXPANDED REVIEW:


Our anime group, Salt Lake City (SLC) Anime, reviewed Log Horizon this month and here is what the group thought:


There were several Pros and Cons about Log Horizon, and these all differed depending on the person. Log Horizon is not like Sword Art Online, in that there is not a lot of action. There is a lot of strategic, political planning. This is not bad at first, but carried on through the whole series. I mean, it’s an MMORPG, there should be battles at some point.


There is a lot of interaction with NPCs, or People of the Land as they are referred to. This also means that there is more of a political system in the world.


Besides the first episode, there is hardly a mention of leaving the virtual world until the last episode. It makes it seem as if nobody cares that they are stuck in a video game. It is a 25 episode season, and you never see what their life is outside the virtual world, and it hardly even gets mentioned that this is not their real life.


There are a lot of characters with a lot of stories, and many of the character’s stories get left in the dust because there is too much going in. This ties into the romantic interests of the characters. While there is not a lot of romance in the anime, what little love interest exists is inconsistent throughout the season.


Log Horizon does a great job at explaining basic MMORPG terminology and blending that into episodes. People not familiar with the MMORPG world will be able to understand the virtual world well.


It takes a while for many of the characters to grow on you. A lot of them have a stereotypical introduction, but then develop as the season progresses. Others seem to get ignored, and you only see them every couple episodes even though they were a prominent character at the beginning of the season.


Overall, SLC Anime enjoyed Log Horizon, giving it a favorable review. Just remember, once again, not to compare it to Sword Art Online.

I'm a sucker for video game/isekai anime. After finishing SAO (before the newer seasons came out), I was looking for something similar to watch. EVERYONE who I knew that had a remote interest in anime told me to watch Log Horizon, and how it was so much better than SAO. 
After watching a good majority of it, I can conclusively say I don't understand why people say that this is WAY better than SAO. I'm not saying SAO was this fantastic, God-given gift to the anime world, it definitely has some glaring flaws and issues, but how people can say Log Horizon is "way" betteris beyond me. Are No Game No Life and Re:Zero better than SAO? Yeah, I could agree with that, but not Log Horizon. 


In watching this series, I have paused or dropped it around three or four times. Not because the animation is bad, not because the characters are bad, not because the sound is bad, no, not any of that, although I'll cover those later in the review. No, my biggest complaint about Log Horizon is how dreadfully boring it is. Every time I come back to watching it, I am constantly reminded of why I dropped it in the first place. 


Before I elaborate, let me briefly explain this show's high points. The animation and design of the Elder Tale world and characters are very clean. Each of the backgrounds have a stunning attention to detail, and the different characters introduced have interesting designs and personalities (for the most part). 


The sound is also a great strength of Log Horizon. Similar to many other fantasy-themed anime, there's a very "olde" vibe to the more Renaissance-related areas, whereas more action-packed scenes have the typical but effective music that is similar to a good majority of shounen anime. The OP is also blood-pumping. I NEVER skip it. 


The characters are either hit or miss. While I previously mentioned that  I loved the character designs, there were only a few that I actually ended up feeling really attached to. Shiroe is a pretty awesome protagonist. While he isn't necessarily creative in the "guy with glasses makes witty and intelligent remarks while everyone oohs and ahhs" area, his cunning and calculating nature makes for a very compelling protagonist. Nyanta is your typical badass, really nothing more to say there other than he's just a fun and wise character who is really enjoyable to watch. Krusty is pretty compelling too. And although this might be an unpopular opinion, I have enjoyed Marielle's character from the start. Her humor is extremely contagious and her bubbly persona is very endearing and charming.


If I didn't mention a character, it's because I either didn't care for them or didn't remember them. I don't mind Naotsugu's goofiness, but he just isn't memorable despite being a protagonist. Akatsuki's character is honestly just disappointing. She's supposedly a powerful high-level ninja, but you rarely ever see that considering she serves as Henrietta's dress-up loli doll for eighty percent of the plot. I don't mind Henrietta either, but her obsession with Akatsuki was unneeded and annoying. Rundellhous was pretty cool too, but similar to Naotsugu, he didn't really leave an impression on me. (Although there is a pretty great plot twist involving him that I won't spoil).

Another issue that I had is a good chunk of the characters are already high-level players, giving little room for any meaningful character development. 


Onto the story, the primary reason that I wrote this review in the first place. I already mentioned it, but I've dropped this series multiple times for one reason; it's simply just a boring show. While it follows a similar plot to SAO with players being trapped in a video game, the danger isn't there. In SAO, you die in game, you die IRL. In Log Horizon, nothing happens to you aside from respawning and losing any items or money that you weren't smart enough to store (unless you're an NPC, in which case you are unfortunately "all-dead"). This effectively eliminates any real danger. This also plays into the conflict of when a character is "in danger." I can't understand how there is any real danger to begin with when the worst that can happen is you is losing your items. This lack of danger also plays into the severe lack of a conflict. Multiple times I've been told "it gets better the longer you've watched it." Eighteen episodes in, and there has been close to no central conflict that poses the characters. You could say "Well, you haven't watched all of it, so how would you know?" For all I know, there is a very good chance that the plot picks up towards the end of the series, but therein lies the problem. It shouldn't take this long for a compelling conflict to be established. 


If this show was advertised as a "slice of life", I think I'd be less harsh on it. But no, Log Horizon is not a slice of life at all. No where will you find anything that suggests Log Horizon is even remotely a slice of life. "Action" and "Adventure" are two of the genres listed, despite both being, for the most part, absent for a good majority of the show's run. I usually have no problem with slices of life, since going into it, I KNOW that the plot and story are not as important as the characters. This is why I enjoyed "Miss Kobyashi's Dragon Maid" and "Sakamoto desu ga?" because going into them, I knew that neither would have a concrete plot considering they were slices of life, and I enjoyed both for their charm and how their characters interacted. This show plays out as a slice of life for a good half of the run, focusing less on the actual plot, and more about how the characters adapt to their new world, but again, that's NOT what this genre is.


Another minor gripe I have is that the language of the show is pretty bizarre. You have a character in the first few or so episodes saying "We're gonna kick your ass", to Akatsuki calling Naotsugu the very childish insult, "turd". I mean it's very clearly not a kid's show, so why the creators thought it was necessary to use such childish language was beyond me.


Again, I DON'T dislike Log Horizon, but my expectations (I guess that's partly my fault) of what the show was meant to be were not met in the slightest. I'd find myself falling asleep at certain episodes because of how devoid of an interesting conflict they were. As I previously mentioned, SAO is NOT perfect at all, but in terms of world-building and the presence of a conflict and plot, it absolutely dominates Log Horizon and drives it into the pixelated ground.


I'm sure if I watch a bit more, my opinion might change, but for now, I'm not going to waste investing my time in it.

This is an MMORPG oriented anime at heart, but as it goes on it diverges quite a bit. It starts off going very in depth into MMO mechanics, especially those related to team work. There's a very strong tactical edge to everything that happens, which makes sense as the main character is a well known strategist. There's a lot of clever use and abuse of various mechanics to accomplish various objectives. There's a dichotomy of having two stories running side by side, one involving high leveled players that are experts on the game and are dealing with things at a high scale and one involvinglow leveled players learning how the game functions from the basics, thus giving the viewers a look into both aspects. However, as it goes on the MMO mechanics begin to matter less and less. This is in part because as it goes on, it becomes clear the world is very different from Elder Tale, and rather than being virtual, it becomes more and more evident that it is an actual world, or at least that's what it seems, which is a very interesting twist on how such stories normally go. The stories still stay focused around tactics, mechanics, and increasingly politics, as opposed to action, though the stories resemble more stories that would take place in a real world than an MMO. Overall, these stories were incredibly good, in that they were interesting stories in their own right and they also developed the world quite well, though the last story felt like a weak plot to close the anime on. However, there was an issue in that it felt like there was never much danger, in that death, even after revealing its consequence, never seemed to matter. Still, watching Shiroe pull out crazy plans out of nowhere and watch them execute tremendously well was incredibly satisfying.


There are a lot of characters, to the point its pretty hard to choose who the main characters would be. Shiroe would definitely be the key main character, and he is an incredibly awesome one, but beyond that there are over a dozen characters that feel like they have the same importance and get the same amount of development. The end result of this is that while Shiroe ends up getting some solid development, as do his relationship with others, with the exception of Crusty and Princess Corwen, pretty much everyone's elses's characters and relationships felt kind of underdeveloped. There is quite a variety in the cast of characters that are all used quite well and they are quite likable in the time they're given however.


The art and animation felt noticeably low budget. I generally don't mind, and even here I didn't mind much, but it was incredibly obvious. The soundtrack was decent but forgettable. The OP was great. The ED was solid.


An anime that features an incredible tactician in an MMO pulling off amazing plans, however somewhat lacking in terms of character development and production values.


8/10

I remember looking at the MAL entry for this anime and thinking to myself: "probably not worth my time." BOY was I wrong!
After a bit a friend of mine recomended this anime to me. I was going into it with high expectations due to how much that friend of mine hyped it up for me, which is always a good way to be massively disapointed. Plot twist: I was not disapointed.
Man this show is awesome. If you're a fan of games and good worldbuilding, this show is definitly a great one to pick up. 
The characters are awesome. Each of them is likable in theirown way. Shiroe is a great protagonist for this show.\n\n
The writing isn't without its flaws, but honestly, they are not even close to being big enough to have an impact in the quality of the show.\n\n
I enjoyed watching this a lot. And by a lot I mean 10/10. That's the rating I give this show. I was hesitating as to whether I should give 10, but I honestly believe the 1st season of Log Horizon deserves it.

~DISCLAIMER~
I would like to formally say that this is my first review ever, and although I don't think it should make my points any less credible it is a fact that you, the reader, should know.
Also, I haven't seen the second season of Log Horizon, and I'm not sure if I ever will.
~OVERVIEW~
I wanted to really like Log Horizon. Like seriously. When I started this I really hated Sword Art Online, but by the end of it I ended up rewatching a bit of SAO and coming to gradually like SAO. Log Horizon is kind of plain boring. It brings very little things new tothe table and goes about it slowly, making it almost feel like a SoL. Its pacing is painfully slow, and a lot of arcs could've taken a lot less episodes, which could've fit in a lot more content.


~STORY~ (minor spoilers)

Log Horizon is like your friend who was way too into Steven Universe and liked to express that by shoving the entire storyline of the episode he rewatched last night and why it is so deep and a commentary on our society, and this and that and blah blah blah (so sorry SU fans, I know a lot of you are pretty cool people. Don't worry, the person I'm talking about is actually me 3 years ago).

Log Horizon finds great pleasure in exploring its world's politics, but has hard time getting you to care about it too. The truly largest problem that the group faces is dealt with off the screen, and instead they show you the importance of a character who (looks and acts exactly like Guiche from Zero no Tsukaima) I find pretty annoying and is only used as an outlet to show off a strong and important concept to the show that is used only once and only talked about after. The ending to the show I find very unsatisfying. The situation that they deal with is "Oh no they're being completed asses and making our festival somewhat chaotic. This must be some dastardly plan to make us look bad and interfere with our relationship with the King!" To counter this, they employ a strange strategy that realistically would not work or be efficient. The perpetrator is has another boring plan. He basically lies, forces the cast to make a minor mistake, and everyone finds it so extreme that it will mess with political affairs. Then he acts like a dick for like, ten minutes. When they call him on his bluff thinking that they're geniuses, the perp storms off in panic mode when the teacher finds out his dog didn't really eat his homework.


(um bigger spoilers i guess.)

I would also like to talk about the pacing once more. It is really painstakingly slow. The arc where the cast is residing in the Eastal Castle of whatyoumacallit lasted a whole ten episodes. It could've been sped up entirely, but the show sliced half of those episodes to develop side characters that I could care less about. The entire development really was Minori finally decided to not be shy and Rudy becomes slightly less annoying and arrogant.


(edit+big spoilers. Like seriously, skip this if you haven't watched the anime/)

I forgot to mention this, but I feel the writers screwed up when they wrote in the "you lose memories if you die" concept. They eliminated the consequence of death early, so they should've just rolled with that and created a more chill story, almost SoL (but thats just my take.)

The consequence they came up with feels like 

"Oh I want there to be a consequence to dying."

"Why?"

"Because we need people to care."

"So, how about we make them lose memories?"

"Thats great! Let's just make it so tiny that it won't really matter, but have the characters act like the world is ending!"

"Why?"

"It's not like we're actually gonna write bad outcomes or consequences in of course. Are you stupid?"


~ART~

The art is nothing to be proud of. A lot of the colors just awkwardly mesh together. The color palette is really bland, which contrasts a lot of the vibrant things in this anime. Also, I find the UI for the game commands to be very busy, and unappealing. I don't plan on mentioning other anime much in my reviews, but SAO is a a good comparison to this. Although I find its characters hollow and its story leaving much to be desired, you have to give it credit for its art. Everything is pops out and really gives off the game aesthetic. The game UI is very clean and easy for the viewer to interpret. Log Horizon feels like an art project where you lost all your good pencil crayons and were forced to color it in with your bad ones. The character designs reflect their character as a whole. And that is basic, cliché, and boring.


~CHARACTER~

I see three groups of people in Log Horizon. The adult crew, the kid crew, and the side characters.


The adult crew consists of Akatsuki, Naotsugu, Nyanta, Serara, and Shiroe. They follow a lot for stereotypes which leads me to believe that these characters were made to be loved instead of to play a part in the story. And I'm probably right. The assassin-shy love interest girl, the outgoing-pervert who says a lot of pointless things that could've been funnier if written differently, the cool swordsman-cat person, and the little girl who's in love awwwhhhh. Shiroe is the only one who is intriguing.  He approaches the world he's been trapped in a different way from anyone else and even the tradition, real life gamer. He's able to think 5 steps ahead and come up with unique and solid plans. However, thats as far as it goes.


The kid crew should be obvious if you've watched the anime. Without wasting time, I'll quickly boil them down in even simpler sentences. The upbeat brother, the shy sister, the regular girl, and the arrogant *cough* Guiche *cough* guy.


I believe that at least one side character should be interesting enough to almost have their own spin off show, but a lot of these characters in Log Horizon fall short. Marielle and Henrietta complete the "one who doesn't want to work-person who makes them work" combo. Henrietta does have her moments though. Krusty is just the skilled, smart, cool guy, who I actually deem somewhat important to represent an actual gamer and make the story so be it, a bit more fleshed out.


~FINAL THOUGHTS~

Log Horizon could be better if it revised its cast and story just a bit more. The anime's main problems lie in the fact that the characters are bland, the story is boring, and the conflicts aren't engaging. Again, I haven't seen season two, but I hope that they do realize this then. None of the other characters stand out at all.


I give Log Horizon a 6.5/10.

Thank you for reading this review.

Log Horizon is actually the first show I ever watched that's built around the concept of being stuck inside a game, preferably an MMORPG. It's certainly not the first fantasy show I've watched, and also not one that's based on a certain game (which Log Horizon isn't), but I'm just throwing this out here anyway, mostly because at first, Log Horizon was inevitably compared to similar "stuck in the game" shows like dot Hack or Sword Art Online. I throw this out now, so that you won't wonder why I won't compare Log Horizon to either of them -- I simply have no basis forcomparison outside of some minor information about either of the two.


This might also be why Log Horizon chooses to dispense with the "if you die in the game, you die for real" angle in the first episode; it simply isn't happening. Characters who fall in battle simply revive in a chapel, seemingly no worse for wear. In its place, we're pretty much served the mystery of how everyone ended up living inside a game, because nobody among the main characters know, and, naturally, panic and confusion spread among the captured players, each choosing to deal with that in their own way, whether that be flaunting guild influence or resorting to stalking and PKing.

In this world, Shiroe actually represents something of a rising trend in anime; the intelligent, resourceful male lead who doesn't just rush in without a second thought, expecting everything to just sort itself out if they just believe hard enough. Granted, I'm taking all the technobabble and "strategy" in this show with a pinch of salt, but he still gets the benefit of the doubt simply because he considers his options before doing things. Problems and its solutions aren't always a simple matter of just beating through them with whatever weapons he has at hand. The show reveals him to be a college graduate, which at least lends some credence to his level of intelligence... as presented by the series.

The idiot role is mostly filled by Naotsugu. Not as much because he's incapable -- he's a level 90 character, like many others among the main cast -- but because he tends to be the butt of most of the jokes. During much of the beginning, he's liable to say something perverted, which earns himself a knee or a foot to the face from Akatsuki, the third part of our main trio. Akatsuki is actually a bit of a curiosity, because the first time you see the character, you see a fairly tall male assassin character... that speaks with a female voice. Having played with their team before, she simply didn't really speak a whole lot, if at all, so when their residence in the game turns somewhat permanent, the first thing she does is to request an appearance-changing potion from Shiroe. Like Shiroe and Naotsugu, she's a level 90 character, meaning she's easily as capable as the others, but since her voice would have been an obvious giveaway, she never really joined any guilds or groups for long amounts of time. So let it be no slight on her capabilities as a player (or assassin, as the situation stands) when I say her female form is downright adorable. It's also relatively short, so of course they had to make a joke about how surprising it was when she revealed she was at least as old as Shiroe. She is one of the most prominent of the female characters, which does say a little about the female characters in this show; they tend to become victims, joke vessels or relegated to support role. It's a bit ironic, given that the main character in this show has chosen a gamer class that's solely a support class, yet still manages to steal the limelight more often than not, even in battle. Even as the most capable of the female characters, Akatsuki still swears allegiance to Shiroe, even if it's to repay him for giving her a very valuable item. She doesn't necessarily adapt a completely servile personality style, though, so take that as you will.

Curiously enough, Log Horizon also has one of the few cat GUYS I've seen in anime. Beast races are apparently not entirely uncommon in Eldar Tale, so Log Horizon gives us Nyanta, another old ally of Debauchery Tea Party and also stuck in the game with the rest of them. Funnily enough, he actually carries the most common hallmark of catgirl behavior -- working in the word "nya" into his conversations -- but that ended up being surprisingly easy to get used to. Nyanta is possibly one of the older players in Elder Tale -- and Log Horizon by extension -- and another members of the "intelligence and maturity over guts" lineup of appealing characters.


Perhaps not unwisely, the players in Akihabara -- seriously, that's the town in the game they appear in; a home base of sorts -- decide to settle in as soon as possible before any other actions can be taken, something that doesn't go entirely smoothly. Once past the prerequisite character introduction and world presentation episodes, the show immediately goes off on a rescue mission. Aside from the aforementioned potion, which is apparently a very rare items in Elder Tale, Shiro and Naotsugu seemingly owns a lot of rare items, presumably from the time the two spent in a kind of freelance group called "Debauchery Tea Party", an adventuring group with people who had no interest in creating a guild. But even beyond that, there's the minor problem of PKers, and the somewhat bigger problems of low-level characters being headhunted into guilds that end up taking advantage of them in downright slavery-like ways. As viewers, we also have to contend with a lot of tutorials in how the game of Elder Tale works, or just MMORPGs in general, and for people who already know most of this, it can get pretty aggravating after a while.

The show eventually moves on from that, thankfully, and it goes through quite a few plot arcs within its runtime of 25 episodes. In a sense, that is also Log Horizon's greatest weakness, because you never really get a good feel of what the show is about. You'd think it would be about what happened with Elder Tale and how so many people literally got stuck inside of it, unable to log out, but past the initial panic attack, people seem strangely unconcerned with it. In fact, just about everyone is a little bit too keen on becoming a permanent part of the new Elder Tale, even though nobody really knows what's going on back in the real world. Are their bodies still there? Will their continued presence in Elder Tale negatively affect said bodies? In short, what is going on? But while dying in the game doesn't seem to affect anyone in any significant way, it might have some other unfortunate side effects that will make themselves more apparent over time.

The other big mystery hanging over the whole gaming world of Log Horizon is its character cast, aka the NPCs. In the game before the apocalypse, most of them were of the simple "I like Swords" variety, but now that everyone is living inside Elder Tale, all the "people of the land" seems to have gotten a serious personality upgrade, to the point that they're almost completely indistinguishable from the heroes (aka "the adventurers".) One of the subplots actually revolve around said NPCs approaching the heroes with diplomatic (and some secretive) designs on their minds. Their new personality upgrade also comes with the added problem of their deaths being quite permanent, which also becomes somewhat of an issue later on.


Fragmented story progression aside, Log Horizon has this offbeat quality to it that I rather like. Even though it's heavily steeped in MMORPGisms, I can always get behind a good fantasy with various facets of its world building to its name, and despite the fact that the players in Elder Tale takes to the ultimate in virtual reality concerning RPGs -- which I'm sure a lot of gamers have had fantasies about -- it's both complex and compelling enough to remain interesting through its entire runtime. Some of the later plot lines kind of feels like they're being abandoned, but a second season was announced about the time the first finished, so it doesn't feel quite as much as a copout as it would have been, had this been the sole season available. As it is, I'm looking forward to the second season. There are still so many things here I want to know.

- English Review (Translated version)
"Great, another anime about people getting caught up in the virtual world of a video game, how original." This was my first thought when I read the synopsis of "Log Horizon" and it was obviously loaded with a mixture of irony and boredom. Luckily something clicked on me and I decided to give it a try despite the unflattering initial premise. And I say luckily because it was a pleasant surprise finally. In another boast of originality, but this time for my part, during the review I will make different comparisons with "SAO" (never seen, right?). Basically I'm going to dothis because for some reason that I can't understand, "SAO" is the flagship in terms of popularity (not quality, no, because it's mediocre to puke) of this sub-genre and I think it's a good yardstick to compare two products with similar backgrounds. If you're passionate about Kazuto's (and company) insufferable firecracker anime you'd better stop reading here, because as I already did in his own review, I'm going to put it back in the broth in the mentions, which is what he deserves.


First of all, one of the most remarkable things about "Log Horizon" is that it reflects perfectly what routine would be like in a virtual world in which people from the real world have become trapped (within the possibilities, as this is obviously speculation). From the initial confusion, through a process of depression and criminality, until people begin to organize themselves in order to prosper, although with a multitude of conflicts and clashes along the way, of course. Pure human nature. The great achievement is to teach us this from a global perspective. Obviously there is a protagonist and there are main characters, but at all times we can observe the evolution that has taken place as a unit, the way in which the "world" of the game grows and changes. This is appreciated because it offers a great backdrop and helps a lot to create an environment in which the audience is able to immerse themselves. Although it has an eminently fantastic theme, everything feels real, true in "Log Horizon". In contrast to "SAO", where everything is centred on the children of a couple of insubstantials and everything else around them is relegated to such a secondary plane that it is not credible.


The story, even without being a wonder or anything that will mark a before and after in the history of anime, is interesting and flows at a good pace, without peaks but without downturns, constant in quality and interest. It is worth noting that despite having a main plot where most of the storyline is based, different sub-plots are gradually being incorporated that give a great deal of variety to the development and that sometimes represent a respite between combats, alliances and meetings. In this sense it is also appreciated that from time to time there is a funny, comical tone, since having that touch also helps that diversity and makes the story much more enjoyable. A good mix of serious tone and carefree tone is difficult to achieve, but if done correctly it is a great success and "Log Horizon" does it. This is much better than simply being a story with great potential, but nurtured by a horrific development and taking itself too seriously (does it ring any bells?).


Another of the strengths of the anime, probably the most important, are the characters. The number is quite high, but even so they all have a strong personality and at no time give the impression that they are for simple stuffing. On the other hand, the protagonist is not the typical jerk of this kind of story. It is true that he may sin to be so great in "his own" (strategic combat and planning), but he does not have that aura of false perfection that is so hard to believe. He has weaknesses and vulnerabilities, as he acknowledges in the series. In that sense I appreciate it, because few things are more annoying to me than a protagonist who does everything right, is perfect and does not fail in anything, everyone loves and admires him... Unsufferable. Anyway, as I have already mentioned, Shiroe is not the only good character in "Log Horizon". I could name Akatsuki, Naotsugu, Minori, Henrietta... all characters very different from each other and who pack the story in their own way. The only thing that squeaks at me (and too much even to make my personal impression worse) is that ambiguity about the romantic-loving subject involving characters like Minori or even Serara, who are underage, childs directly. There is nothing explicit, it cannot even be considered "serious", but they play with a kind of confusion and double meanings that are not acceptable. Seriously, that's completely superfluous.


About the technical section, artistically it is more than enough. Well-drawn scenarios, surprising effects and magic. You can't ask for a single but, because the medieval-fantastic atmosphere is perfectly recreated. As for the sound section, the melodies sound very, very good, they have more than acceptable quality. Some of them would sound in any JRPG. The opening is horrible and completely anticlimactic, it doesn't fit in with the style and theme of "Log Horizon". Lousy choice. The ending, however, is very, very good, with it they have been right. By the way, it is precisely in the case of opening that the overvalued "SAO" will hardly outperform "Log Horizon". Because in "SAO" the opening is an absolute geniality interpreted by LiSA and that is difficult to overcome it. To conclude, I applaud the fact that in "Log Horizon" they have used only one opening/ending all season. This is what all studios should do in these seasons of just over 20 chapters. People, with only one opening/ending is more than enough in so few chapters, because it helps to create an identity and an identification with the anime, something that gets complicated if you start to put different openings/endings in a short time. If bands want to promote themselves, they could make videos on Youtube, but it's dantesque to see things like three openings in a season of 20 and few chapters (cof, cof, "Code Geass").



- Spanish Review (Original and faithful version)


"Genial, otro anime sobre gente que se queda atrapada en el mundo virtual de un videojuego, qué original". Este fue mi primer pensamiento cuando leí la sinopsis de "Log Horizon" por primera vez y obviamente estaba cargado de una mezcla entre ironía y hastío. Por suerte algo me hizo click y decidí darle una oportunidad a pesar de lo poco halagüeño de la premisa inicial. Y digo por suerte porque ha sido una agradable sorpresa. En otro alarde de originalidad, pero esta vez por mi parte, durante la crítica voy a establecer diferentes comparaciones con "SAO" (nunca visto, ¿verdad?). Básicamente voy a hacer esto porque por alguna razón que no alcanzo a entender, "SAO" es el buque insignia en cuanto a popularidad (en cuanto a calidad no, porque es mediocre hasta vomitar) de este subgénero y creo que es una buena vara de medir el comparar dos productos con similar trasfondo. Si te apasiona el anime del petardo insufrible de Kazuto (y compañía) será mejor que dejes de leer aquí, porque como ya hiciera en su review propia, voy a volver a ponerla a caldo en las menciones que haga, que es lo que merece.


De primeras una de las cosas más destacables de "Log Horizon" es que plasma perfectamente cómo sería la rutina en un mundo virtual en el que gente del mundo real ha quedado atrapada (dentro de las posibilidades, ya que obviamente son especulaciones). Desde la confusión inicial, pasando por un proceso de depresión y criminalidad, hasta que la gente empieza a organizarse para conseguir prosperar, aunque con multitud de conflictos y choques en el camino, por supuesto. Pura naturaleza humana. El gran acierto es enseñarnos esto desde una perspectiva global. Obviamente hay un protagonista, hay personajes principales, pero en todo momento podemos observar la evolución que se ha producido en conjunto, el cómo "el mundo" del juego crece y cambia. Esto es algo que se agradece porque ofrece un gran trasfondo y ayuda muchísimo a crear un ambiente en el que el espectador sea capaz de sumergirse. A pesar de tener una temática eminentemente fantástica todo se siente real, verdadero en "Log Horizon". Al contrario que ocurre en "SAO", donde todo está centrado en las niñatadas de un par de insustanciales y lo que hay alrededor queda relegado a un plano tan secundario que hace que no sea creíble (a pesar de los majestuosos y espectaculares escenarios, que en eso es genial).


La historia, aún sin ser un portento ni nada que vaya a marcar un antes y un después en la historia del anime, es interesante y va fluyendo a buen ritmo, sin picos pero sin bajones, constante en calidad y en interés. Es un punto a destacar que a pesar de tener una trama principal donde se sustenta la mayor parte del peso argumental, se van incorporando poco a poco diferentes subtramas que le dan bastante variedad al desarrollo y que a veces suponen un respiro entre combates, alianzas y reuniones. En este sentido se agradece también que de vez en cuando haya un tono divertido, cómico, ya que contar con ese toque ayuda también a esa diversidad y hace mucho más agradable la historia. Una buena mezcla entre lo serio y lo desenfadado es difícil de realizar, pero si se lleva a cabo correctamente es un gran acierto y en "Log Horizon" ocurre así. Mucho mejor esto que ser simplemente una historia con gran potencial, pero que naufrada con un desarrollo horroroso y por tomarse demasiado en serio a sí misma (¿os suena de algo?).


Otro de los puntos fuertes del anime, probablemente el que más, son los personajes. El número es bastante elevado, pero aun así todos cuentan con una personalidad bastante marcada y en ningún momento dan la sensación de que estén para simple relleno. Por otra parte, el protagonista no es el típico pelmazo que abunda en este tipo de historias. Es cierto que puede pecar de ser "un hacha" en lo suyo (combate estratégico y planificación), pero no tiene ese aura de falsa perfección tan difícil de creer. Tiene sus debilidades y sus puntos flacos, él mismo lo reconoce en la propia serie. En ese sentido yo lo agradezco, porque pocas cosas se me hacen más coñazo que ese protagonista al que todo le sale bien, es perfecto y no falla en nada, todo el mundo le quiere y admira... Insufrible. De todas formas, como ya he comentado, Shiroe no es el único buen personaje de "Log Horizon". Podría nombrar a Akatsuki, Naotsugu, Minori, Henrietta... todos personajes muy diferentes entre sí y que dan empaque a la historia cada uno a su forma. Lo único que me chirría (y además muchísimo, tanto como para empeorar mi impresión personal) es esa ambigüedad al respecto del tema romántico-amoroso implicando a personajes como Minori o incluso Serara, que son menores de edad, niñas directamente. No hay nada explícito, ni siquiera se puede considerar "serio", pero juegan con una especie de confusiones y dobles sentidos que no son de recibo. En serio, eso sobra por completo.


En cuanto al apartado técnico, artísticamente cumple con creces. Escenarios bien dibujados, efectos y magias que sorprenden. No se le puede pedir ni un pero, porque la atmósfera fantástico-medieval está recreada a la perfección. En cuanto al apartado sonoro, las melodías suenan muy, muy bien, son de una calidad más que aceptable. Algunas darían el pego en cualquier JRPG que se precie. Aunque no puedo dejar de comentar que el opening es horrible y completamente anticlimático, no cuadra lo más mínimo con el estilo y la temática de "Log Horizon". Pésima elección. El ending sin embargo es muy, muy bueno, con él sí han acertado de pleno. Por cierto, precisamente en esto del opening sería en lo poco que la sobrevalorada "SAO" supere a "Log Horizon". Y es que en "SAO" el opening es una genialidad absoluta interpretada por LiSA y eso es complicado de superar. Para terminar diré que aplaudo a rabiar que en "Log Horizon" hayan usado un solo opening/ending en toda la temporada. Es lo que deberian hacer todos los estudios en estas temporadas de poco más de 20 capítulos. Señores, con un opening/ending es más que suficiente en tan pocos capítulos, ya que gracias a ello se consigue una identidad propia y una identificación del mismo con el anime, algo que se complica si empiezas a meter diferentes openings/endings en poco tiempo. Si los grupos musicales se quieren promocionar que hagan vídeos en Youtube, pero es dantesco ver cosas como tres openings en una temporada de 20 y pocos capítulos (cof, cof, "Code Geass").

Ok, so there is hate on SAO for being bad, well, as a person that enjoyed SAO I can understand that feeling of "meh" now. There is no weight to the story - players are immortal, there is nothing to loose. Yes - death removes a bit of memories, but we see Shiro die over and over again later in series and there is no negative effect, like it is forgotten at all. There is no real drive to care for the pleople of the land - they are NPCs, yes they take up maintenance of town, but players can do it just fine too,as we are shown that quite early in the story. Living is dirty cheap, only drawback tastless food, but it means as long as you kill atleast a couple of monster, you can go by just fine living in inn, as well as buying food. So... What should we care about in anime, where MC and his guild are immortal, can go by without dying, because normal monster and even armies of monsters are too weak to threaten them? There are to stakes there, characters are 2d in every possible way. Shiro is smart, Cat is good chef and womanizer, paladin is perv, ninja is tsundere - all you will get out of the main cast. If you want somewhat decent stuck in a game anime go watch SAO, or hack// series, atleast there is something to be lost if they die.

So what everyone thinks when they first start watching Log Horizon is that its a cheap rip-off of Sword Art Online. but that couldn't be further from the truth don't get me wrong they're both stuck in MMORPG's but they have very different story lines the main character of Log Horizon is nothing like Kirito from SAO hes a strategist that thinks about everything he does first he reminded me a lot of Light yagami from death note which made the idea of this show quite refreshing. i hear a lot of poeple complain about kirito in SAO because hes to much of the typical"Hero type" main character so if youre not into that this might be a little more your style. i feel like some of the voice acting probably could have been better but don't get me wrong it dosent make a huge difference. Overall it was a great show and i can't wait to read the manga

Story: 
A popular MMO just got an update and everyone who downloaded it right when it went live are sent into the "digital world" and now they are the characters they created. The would be Players our main character Shiroe must adapt to this new land, level up, and get loot drops. 
Art:
Generic 2010s anime art style, with a wide variety in the color pallet.
Sound:
Monsters, sword clashes, and things falling all sound decent. The Dub is also well done and no characters voice seems out of place.
Characters: We have three starkly different characters team up
Shiroe - Basically the laid back genius (like shikamaru from naruto)He seems to always be thinking one step ahead of everyone else. He extremely skilled and when he needs to be a great manipulator, thus the reason he was nicknamed "The Villian in Glasses" (also he's a Enchanter)\n\n
Naotsugu - The Meat head, he's a very happy go lucky kind of dude. He has a habbit of making some good natured dirty jokes, and cheering up his friends. (He's the Tank)\n\n
Akatsuki - Then we have this girl the wannabe Ninja(though she actaully is a Assassin class)Originally she played as a guy character as to not be noticed but when the update happened she ended up in a weird situation and thanks to Shiroe was able to be a girl. She has pledged her loyalty to him since, (aint that cute) only addressing him a "My Lord".\n\n
Enjoyment:\n
Though Log Horizon doesnt bring anything new to the table. It's fun to see how the players evolve from people being stranded in a new world to hard working members of the community. With Shiroe at the forefront to lead them all, whether they want to follow or not. At times this Anime is very light hearted(like pokemon) and others its almost like a mind game(like Classroom of the Elites) or political war.(like Gate)\n\n
Overall:\n
This animes fun to watch and decently interesting. While you may not feel for the character you come to like them(or atleast one of them hopefully)

Although Log Horizon is produced earlier than the “famous Sword Art Online,”  in some sense, this anime has way better in the plot and has better content—though there is less fan service—while having the same genre.  Revolves around the virtual world and gaming; so if you are not playing MMORPGs or other online games, or if you aren’t into gaming in general, I think that it might take you longer to catch up with what is going on in this anime.  However, it does not mean that you would not be able to enjoy it.  This anime contains bits of romance,tons of comedy, and a lot of adventure; so it would be fit for any anime viewer that has an open mind and a general view about the anime world.  When you finish this anime, you’ll want to watch more and learn about its story after the ending. 

The story mainly revolves around the fact that the main characters perform a great job while being in a different world.  Shiroe, the main character, is someone that is very cunning, strong-willed and is also a great strategist-characteristics fit for a leader especially in MMORPGs. Despite his “class” in the game, he leads his people (other players closely-related to him) to achieve great things.

The hook in this anime is that the characters are stuck in a game without any way to get out of it.  Shiro makes the world interesting by bringing back the players into the mood of being able to “live normal” again. (Watched early 2015)

Log Horizon is an extremely well written science fiction story, with terrible directing and borderline annoying comedy relief. The concepts and execution of those concepts are very well fleshed out and intelligent. It's not just a competent story, it's a great story. The directing is flat and boring, with only the most engaging moments in the story actually effective in their presentation. The comedy, with very few exceptions, is one joke assigned to a character that makes you smile slightly the first time it happens, and then this joke repeated with no variation over and over.
I can off handedly remember about15 moments in the entire season that were actually effectively directed in a way that I'd enjoy watching again, and one really great scene that was very well directed and enjoyable to watch. Every time I try to think about an episode that I've already watched, I remember how dull the execution is and don't feel like rewatching it. The story is great, but since I already know how it plays out, actually watching the show again does not entice me at all.

This is a story about people trapped in an MMORPG with classes and sub classes, it has people who are animal hybrids and how they deal with it. Very familiar right? But it's not exactly like those
If I had to describe Log Horizon and what makes it different from SAO and the .hack//sign I'd use the example of :Id, Ego and SuperEgo.
-SAO is the Id, unrestrained and rather messy at points, focusing on the flash sometimes over the substance beneath. Watching it is the equal to watching a fun but predictable movie like Wonder Woman or Iron man.
-.Hack//sign is the Ego, something more thoughtful butalso still emotionally driven, in some ways this is emotionally the deepest that leaves us thinking about it's implications and emotions involved after we've stopped watching. I'd compare watching it to something like Memento or Green Mile .


-Making Log Horizon the Superego, a look at how to perfect the ideas and distill them into a formula that can be influenced and subverted using the rules of the world. In movie terms The Usual Suspects and the Game, things that keep you in amazement how they pulled it off even 10 minutes or 10 days after turn it off.


Now with that said: 

Log Horizon is all about a strategist and if you like "thinking" anime like Death Note but do want a bit more action this will definitely scratch that itch as it did for me. Almost every attack done by the characters in action scenes who ally themselves with Shiroe, the main character, are done with a purpose that becomes clear even if it's not immediate. And every time the camera zooms in on something or the shot lingers on something during a conversation IT IS IMPORTANT even if you don't think it is at the moment. There are several early bird cameos that you can catch that way of characters who don't appear in talking roles for another 2 or 3 episodes. So in that way I'd have give it a 10/10 in terms of story telling because it's clear the creators and animation company didn't want to waste a moment of screen time and wanted to respect our time as viewers by giving us a full story.


Now All the characters who we meet are also very much nerdy people as this was based around an MMO that they really ddid play, so even the 'dumb' characters have some brain about them. However this doesn't keep them from becoming cliches/sterotypes in their own way including the wise but laidback master character, the perverted best friend (think Ryuji & Yosuke from persona), the loyal female character who is clearly in love with the the lead and even the cute young guy who is something of a ladies man. Due to their intelligence and how they're used to advance the plot which elevates them from being stock anime character # 31238 I give characters a 7/10 . 


The sound an art design are well done but clearly not top notch for animes of this style. Shiroe who wears a giant white/off-white cape that has a red and dark grey pin makes him visually stick out but beside that he's the typical mage character and everyone else has the tropes of "typical fantasy character" and in Akatsuki's case, she wears what is now considered very typical ninja clothing for a fantasy setting. This is not a knock against the style though as it works for what was clearly suppose to an Everquest or FF11 type of fantasy MMORPG and even higher level gear sometimes gives off a generic feeling of a "proper (insert class here)" feel.  The expressions and details , especially in the backgrounds, is where this goes from a 5 to an 8 because they do not skimp out on making sure you get the expansiveness of a hallway or the city.



I did enjoy it very much as I did like seeing a new wrinkle thrown into a genre I know well enough from anime and manga. I believe you owe it to yourself if you like less combat focused series with strategic mind set put forth very much. Just the cliches/character type  of the supporting cast, especially how some gags are repeated a lot in two nearly back to back episodes (One involving paperwork and another involving a character's seemingly platonic affection for Akatsuki, because of how cute she is) wore on my enjoyment a bit.


I'd definitely say give it a few episodes, at least the first 3 to see if you are interested in going further. 9/10

Log Horizon is the story of a gamer named Shiroe and his friends after they are pulled into another world: a fantasy world that closely resembles the highly popular MMORPG, "Elder Tale." For this review, I've chosen not to follow the trope of comparing it to Sword Art Online (or any other anime for that matter). As I watched, I wrote down my chief thoughts on the show as pros and cons.
